title: Family living off-grid on Cornish cliff after giving up city life in London
text:

A mother, her partner and their four children have spoken about how they gave up life in London to live on a cliff top in Cornwall.

Davina Foster and her family moved from London to a field in Perranporth in the hopes of being able to sustain themselves, Cornwall Live reported .

They now live on the side of a cliff in Cornwall with a bunch of pigs, ducks and chickens and a static caravan.

Five years ago, the family lived in a little house in south east London, but Davina found herself idly scrolling through Cornish properties.

She said: "“My son was nine at the time and we were starting to look at secondaries and thinking about the future and the post office in Grampound came up for sale.

“My other half is a builder and I was a photographer and we thought we’d buy it and convert it.

“We fell in love with the idea, put our house on the market, our offer was accepted and our house went up for sale like that.”

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

The family, Davina, now 36, her partner Todd and their children Michael, 15, Saffron, 11, Ruby, 6, and Harry, 18 months, were disappointed and left stumped when their offer for the post office was not accepted.

But their own house in London had been sold, so the decided to move anyway.

They rented a small house in Perranporth, started the children, in schools and ended up buying a derelict old miners’ cottage in Redruth, which Todd worked on renovating while Davina, who had been a professional photographer in London, worked in Spar and the Cornish Pizza Co.

She added: "We had all these bills and all this pressure,” she said. “It was not my ambition from being a successful photographer in London to working in a supermarket.

"And we were beginning to get burnt out by the property thing.

"Todd and I were used to camping - we met working at festivals - so we rented out the house in Redruth and started to look for land.”

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

Eventually, the family's dream plot of land, a seven and three quarter acre agricultural plot became available and they purchased it.

The sale went through and they got four Cornish black pigs and some chickens and started working the land right away.

Davina said: "“We rented locally for that time and we were going up there every day working the land.

"It was just a completely empty field. We had to drag containers of water up the hill.

"On one day our pig arc blew off the cliff and I had to climb down and drag it back up.

"We had no income and we were investing in the land.”

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

But the work was expensive and in a few months they were forced to stop renting and move onto the land.

The mother-of-four said: "“We had a horsebox and a shack Todd built out of some pallets and the bell tent. We had some ducks and some geeses.

“We decided to do 28 days camping because that’s allowed in the scope of the land. Everyone loved it, we got some great reviews.

“But I fell pregnant over that summer and I was sick every single day and all night. I got insomnia, so I didn’t sleep. It was so cold and wet. It just rained and rained.

“And then we went into winter and it was brutal and then in March the Beast from the East came and I swear to god I had snow on the end of my bed and I was eight months pregnant.”

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

In sub zero temperatures, the family’s generator broke, they had no heating, one car battery and a broken solar panel for power and were effectively just about existing through one of the most brutal winters in history.

But the family did not let the weather beat them and persevered, buying two static caravans at the end of March 2018 and moving to a more sheltered part of the field.

The 36-year-old said: "Harry decided to come a week early.

"I was painting the caravans and my waters broke That was last April.

"We didn’t do camping that year. We were stretched to breaking point. We didn’t have the money.

“Over the year that followed we got back on track. We did the summer and winter and winter really wasn’t that bad last year.

"We were living the dream. We had more power - two solar panels and four batteries. We got a telly. We were learning things along the way.”

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

(Image: Greg Martin/Cornwall Live WS)

Since then, Davina and Todd have established Cligga Cliff Farm at the heart of the Perranporth community.

The couple are also heavily involved with the Plastic Free Perranporth movement and have even set up a monthly plastic free market.

The family have also brought cows to their land starting their own micro-dairy, get day old turkeys in July to rear them up for Christmas and have 16 litters of piglets every year.

Davina said that the family's dream of self-sufficiency was within reach.

She said: ""By the end of next summer we’ll be self sufficient."
description: Davina Foster and her family moved to Cornwall - where they are now living in a field - after falling in love with the idea of moving to the far south west
